HUNGER SURGING AS AN OFFENSIVE PUMMELS RAFAH

OFFICIALS FEAR FAMINE International Court Adds Pressure on Israel to

Exit Gazan City
This article is by Vivian Yee, Bilal
Shbair and Matthew Mpoke Bigg. CAIRO - For weeks, the Gaza
Strip's southernmost city Strip's southernmost city, Rafah,
was one of the few places where desperate Gazans could find some aid and food. Bakeries sold bread;
fuel powered generators; markets were open, if expensive.
But since Israeli forces bega But incursion in the city this month
- effectively closing the two main - effectively closing the two main
crossings where aid enters crossings where aid enters -
Rafah has become a place of fear Ratah has become a place of fear
and dwindling suppplies. Bakeries have shuttered. So have malnutri-
tion treatment centers. The price tion treatment centers. The pric
of the firewood that many people of the firewood that many people
now use to cook has doubled. Tonow use to cook has doubled. To-
matoes, cucumbers and peppers
have grown so expensive that have grown so expensive that
they are sold by the piece, not by they are sold by the piece, not by
the kilogram.
Families Families hide what canned
goods they still have. They eye goods they still have. They eye
their emptying sacks of flour, caltheir emptying sacks of flour, cal-
culating how long they will last. "There's always something
missing in the tent," said Ahmed Abual-Kas, 511 , who is sheltering in Rafah with his family. "If we have
bread, we don't have water. If we have firewood, we don't have some basic vegetables."
For months, international aid For months, international aid
officials and health experts have officials and health experts have

A Landmark Settlement Forces
N.C.A.A.Schools to Pay Players

Since its founding, the N.C.A.A.
has operated with a business mod- More Issues to Solve el that defined the college athlete as an amateur. Over the years, as
college sports evolved into college sports evolved into a
mega-enterprise, lawsuits and labor actions chipped away at that model, which came to be increas-
ingly seen as exploitative in big money sports like football and money basketball.
But the N.C.A.A.s $\$ 2.8$ billion lass-action antitrust lawsuit rep class-action antitrust lawsuit rep-
resents the heaviest blow - and perhaps a decisive one - to that system. If approved by a U.S. distric judge in California, the settlement
would allow for the creation of the first revenue-sharing plan for col lege athletics, a landmark shift in which schools would direct
their athletes for playing. This sea change, though, also carries its own questions, accord-
ing to critics.
whether women would be comensated fairly, whether smaller conferences would bear a dispro-
portionate burden of the settlement and whether this framework would do anything to limit the -funded groups that entice play rs with payments to hopscotc from school to school. "It's both a historic and deeply H. LeRoy a a law professor at University of Illinois. "The idea ollars to the people who are selling the TV contracts and filling the
seats - that's good. But it closes seats - that's good. But it close
one Pandora's box and opens four or five others."
